buyerGroup.name: Stig-Arne Ryeng
buyerGroup.title: Sales Executive
buyerGroup.aiReasoning: Stig-Arne Ryeng is a Sales Executive at M-Files, which makes him moderately relevant for Sales Intelligence Software. As someone in a direct sales role, he would be a daily user and beneficiary of sales intelligence tools that provide lead data, account insights, and prospecting capabilities. His position suggests he's an individual contributor or mid-level sales professional rather than senior leadership, given the 'Sales Executive' title (not VP/Director). His strong LinkedIn presence (1,708 followers with 500+ connections) indicates he's well-networked and potentially influential among peers. In the buying process, he would most likely serve as a 'champion' - someone who recognizes the value of the tool through daily use and can advocate for its adoption to decision-makers. However, at M-Files (a document management software company), the final purchasing authority for a $150K deal would likely rest with a VP of Sales, CRO, or similar senior leader. His influence score of 6/10 reflects that while he can strongly advocate and influence the buying decision through bottom-up validation and demonstrating ROI, he probably lacks final approval authority for a deal of this size. He's relevant enough to engage as he could champion the solution internally and provide critical end-user feedback, but he should not be the sole contact for this opportunity.
buyerGroup.roleReasoning: Promoted to champion (no better candidate found)

aiRoleValidation.reasoning: Stig-Arne Ryeng is already designated as the champion in the existing buyer group, and this assignment should be maintained. As a Sales Executive in the Sales department at M-Files, he is the ideal champion for Sales Intelligence Software because: (1) He will be a direct end-user of the product, giving him intimate knowledge of operational needs and pain points, (2) Sales Intelligence Software directly impacts his daily workflow and performance metrics, creating strong personal motivation to advocate for it, (3) As a Sales Executive, he has credibility with sales leadership and can effectively demonstrate ROI and adoption potential to decision-makers, (4) The $150K deal size suggests this requires executive-level approval beyond his authority, but his operational expertise makes him the perfect internal advocate. He lacks the budget authority typically required for a 'decision' role at this deal size (Sales Executives rarely have $150K discretionary spending), but his position makes him the most invested and knowledgeable champion for driving this purchase forward.

fullProfile.headline: Helping companies improve they way they manage information
fullProfile.summary: Throughout my career, I have always been passionate about building strong relationships with my customers. Mainly, by putting their needs and their return on investment first. I have been privileged to work alongside talented individuals and organizations, and I have helped companies in the Nordic region with the deployment of solutions that enhance their business through increased operational efficiency. All this while providing the highest level of accountability and transparency. I now work at Mintra Group, which is a leading global partner for companies within oil and gas, maritime, construction and renewables looking to achieve cost effective management of HR, competences and training. We unlock the power of competence for our customers. If you would like to learn more about we can help your organization, please contact me at stig-arne.ryeng@mintragroup.com or reach me by phone at +47 481 91 640

buyerGroup.name: Jonathan Comer
buyerGroup.title: Account Executive
buyerGroup.aiReasoning: Jonathan Comer is an Account Executive in the Sales department at M-Files, making him highly relevant for Sales Intelligence Software. As an AE, he would be a direct end-user of sales intelligence tools to prospect, research accounts, and identify decision-makers. His role suggests he would benefit significantly from the product and could champion its adoption. However, several factors limit his decision-making authority: (1) As an individual contributor rather than sales leadership, he lacks budget authority for a $150K purchase, (2) At a company with 100 employees, purchasing decisions of this magnitude likely require VP/C-level approval, (3) While he can strongly influence the decision by demonstrating need and ROI from a user perspective, he's unlikely to be the final signatory. His value lies in being a potential internal champion who can advocate for the solution to leadership, provide use-case validation, and influence the evaluation process. His 500+ connections and 775 followers suggest he's well-networked and could facilitate introductions to decision-makers. Best approach: Position him as a champion who can help navigate to sales leadership (VP Sales, CRO, or CEO at this company size) who would ultimately approve the purchase.
buyerGroup.roleReasoning: Selected as Stakeholder for project influence: Will be affected by implementation and can provide valuable input.

aiRoleValidation.reasoning: Jonathan Comer is already assigned as a stakeholder, which is the optimal role for him given the context. As an Account Executive in the Sales department, he is a direct end-user who will be heavily affected by Sales Intelligence Software implementation - this tool will directly impact his daily workflow, prospecting activities, and sales effectiveness. However, at the Account Executive level, he lacks the budget authority to approve a $150K purchase (decision-maker role) and isn't senior enough to be the primary internal advocate (champion role already filled by Stig-Arne Ryeng, likely a more senior operational leader). His involvement is critical for requirements gathering, user acceptance, and adoption success, but his influence is primarily at the user level rather than executive decision-making level. The existing buyer group structure makes sense: Stig-Arne as champion can drive the initiative strategically while Jonathan represents the end-user perspective as a stakeholder.

However, at the Account Executive level, he lacks the budget authority to approve a $150K purchase (decision-maker role) and isn't senior enough to be the primary internal advocate (champion role already filled by Stig-Arne Ryeng, likely a more senior operational leader). His involvement is critical for requirements gathering, user acceptance, and adoption success, but his influence is primarily at the user level rather than executive decision-making level. The existing buyer group structure makes sense: Stig-Arne as champion can drive the initiative strategically while Jonathan represents the end-user perspective as a stakeholder.
